entry.title: Self-medication: not an alternative to the classical health service provision but an addition to it

link.title: Self-medication: not an alternative to the classical health service provision but an addition to it

entry.summary: Self-medication has a negative connotation attached to it. The established norm is that it is wrong. You are supposed to always consult your doctor. I am not sure how often this is said as a sort of legal hedge (‘I don’t want you to sue me’) or simply out of habit.

entry.title: Accepting a Credit Card: a SaaS application in a nutshell (Stripe, Rails4, Devise3)

link.title: Accepting a Credit Card: a SaaS application in a nutshell (Stripe, Rails4, Devise3)

entry.summary: Recently I blogged about a light-touch workflow which allows registration without setting a password. This blog post and the accompanying git repository take it from there and add credit card registration via Stripe. I was thinking of what could the absolutely minimal SaaS application and came with the conclusion that it recording the credit card details constitutes the absolutely irreducable bit - without it you can’t have a SaaS application. So, this lengthy blog post is about creating such a minimal SaaS application that does nothing but allowing people to sign up and record their credit card details.

entry.title: Overriding Devise to Skip Setting of Password (Rails4, Devise3)

link.title: Overriding Devise to Skip Setting of Password (Rails4, Devise3)

entry.summary: I’ve been thinking about a light-touch workflow which allows a prospective user to register without setting a password. My first idea was to override the confirmable module (i.e. to invite the user to set a password as part of the confirmation) but I dropped it as it introduces an interim state (an unconfirmed account) and for me this is an unnecessary complication. My idea was to make the registration simpler and requiring a confirmation would be the exact opposite.
